raw_text: Gamon (2010) proposes a hybrid system for preposition and article correction, by incorporating the scores of a language model and class probabilities of a maximum entropy model, both trained on native data, into a meta-classifier that is trained ona smaller amount of annotated ESL data
clean_text: Gamon (2010) proposes a hybrid system for preposition and article correction, by incorporating the scores of a language model and class probabilities of a maximum entropy model, both trained on native data, into a meta-classifier that is trained on a smaller amount of annotated ESL data.

raw_text: In contrast to Gamon (2010) and Han et al (2010) that use annotated data for training, the system is trained on native data, but the native data are transformed to be more like L1 data through artificial article errors that mimic the error rates and error patterns of non-native writers. This method is cheaper, since obtaining error statistics requires much less annotated data than training
clean_text: In contrast to Gamon (2010) and Han et al (2010) that use annotated data for training, the system is trained on native data, but the native data are transformed to be more like L1 data through artificial article errors that mimic the error rates and error patterns of non-native writers.

raw_text: Gamon (2010) shows precision/recall curves onthe combined task of detecting missing ,extraneous and confused prepositions
clean_text: Gamon (2010) shows precision/recall curves on the combined task of detecting missing, extraneous and confused prepositions.

raw_text: Gamon (2010) also considers missing and extraneous preposition errors.those that are observed in the non-native data improves both the precision and the recall compared to a classifier that considers as possible candidates the set of all prepositions
clean_text: Gamon (2010) also considers missing and extraneous preposition errors.

raw_text: Some recent work includes Cho do row et al (2007), De Felice and Pulman (2008), Gamon (2010), Han et al (2010), Izumi et al (2004), Tetreault and Chodorow (2008), Rozovskaya and Roth (2010a, 2010b)
clean_text: Some recent work includes Chodorow et al (2007), De Felice and Pulman (2008), Gamon (2010), Han et al (2010), Izumi et al (2004), Tetreault and Chodorow (2008), Rozovskaya and Roth (2010a, 2010b).

raw_text: Gamon et al (2008) and Gamon (2010) used a language model in addition to a classifier and combined the classifier output and language model scores in a meta classifier
clean_text: Gamon et al (2008) and Gamon (2010) used a language model in addition to a classifier and combined the classifier output and language model scores in a meta classifier.

raw_text: Note that this use of a host of language model features is substantially different from using a single language model score on hypothesized error and potential correction to filter out unlikely correction candidates as in Gamon et al (2008) and Gamon (2010)
clean_text: Note that this use of a host of language model features is substantially different from using a single language model score on hypothesized error and potential correction to filter out unlikely correction candidates as in Gamon et al (2008) and Gamon (2010).

raw_text: In Figure 4 we com pare the sequence modeling results for prepositions with results from the preposition component of the current version of the system described in Gamon (2010) on the same test set
clean_text: In Figure 4 we compare the sequence modeling results for prepositions with results from the preposition component of the current version of the system described in Gamon (2010) on the same test set.

raw_text: A third alternative, that of selectively removing or correcting errors, is something of a middle road, and has been used in other work using the CLC data: in particular, Gamon (2010) removes from the data sentences where some other error appears immediately next to a preposition or determiner error
clean_text: A third alternative, that of selectively removing or correcting errors, is something of a middle road, and has been used in other work using the CLC data: in particular, Gamon (2010) removes from the data sentences where some other error appears immediately next to a preposition or determiner error.
